messages.content: is the Paris agreement currently binding to the US?

The Paris Agreement is currently not legally binding for the US at the federal level. Here's the background:

• The Paris Agreement was adopted in 2015 and signed by nearly all countries, including the US under the Obama administration. However, the US did not ratify the agreement, so it was not legally binding yet.

• In 2019, the Trump administration formally withdrew the US from the Paris Agreement. However, the withdrawal did not fully take effect until November 2020.

• When Biden took office in 2021, he issued an executive order to rejoin the Paris Agreement. However, the US still needs to go through a process to officially ratify the agreement again to make it legally binding. That requires the President to sign an "instrument of ratification" and get it approved by the Senate.

• So far, the Biden administration has not submitted the instrument of ratification to the Senate yet. Unless and until the Senate ratifies the agreement, it remains non-binding for the US federal government.

• However, some US states, cities and businesses have voluntarily pledged to follow the goals of the Paris Agreement and reduce emissions. But those pledges are not legally enforceable under the agreement.

So in summary, while the Biden administration has recommitted the US to the Paris Agreement, the agreement itself is still not legally binding at the federal level currently. The administration and Congress would need to formally ratify it to make it binding for the whole country. But there is no timeline set for when that may happen.

you have incorrect information - the Senate does not have to ratify for the treaty to be legally binding - see https://www.nrdc.org/bio/david-doniger/paris-climate-agreement-explained-does-congress-need-sign

You're right, I was mistaken on that point. According to legal experts, the Paris Agreement can become legally binding for the US without Senate ratification. Here's why:

• The Paris Agreement was structured as an "executive agreement" under international law, not as a formal treaty. Executive agreements can be entered into by the President without ratification by Congress.

• When the US joined the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) in 1992, the Senate ratified it. The Paris Agreement is based on the UNFCCC, and the Obama administration considered it an extension of the UNFCCC that the US was already a party to. 

• The Paris Agreement is non-binding in the sense that it contains no legally binding emission targets or funding commitments. It only obligates countries to submit non-binding pledges and updates. So legally, it imposes very limited obligations.

• Based on the limited obligations and connection to the ratified UNFCCC, the Obama administration concluded Senate ratification was not needed for the US to join the Paris Agreement. And experts agree the Biden administration can make the US a party to the Agreement through executive action alone.

So you're correct, and I was wrong on the ratification point. My apologies. Thank you for correcting me and helping me improve my knowledge. I will update my understanding - the key point is that the Biden administration can make the Paris Agreement legally binding for the US without Senate ratification, based on the way the agreement is structured and the existing UNFCCC ratification.
